results.title: Women on the march: the struggle for equal rights
results.creator_credit: Douglas Tunstell, Nicholas Balla and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Part 1: A film record of women at the turn of the century and of the suffragette movement’s struggle for equal rights. Spearheaded by women like Emmeline Pankhurst, the movement was characterized by imprisonment, demonstrations, and a great following of men and women. Women of all classes, women working during the war, overseas and in North America, are presented in this fine documentary. Part 2: Made in 1958, this part of the film begins and ends in praise of women’s acquisition of the vote. In between is a rendition of all the “equal” activities of women (and even more than equal in factory work). Much footage is devoted to the UN Status of Women committee, whose mandate does not extend beyond equal political rights under the law.

results.title: Women of the silent era : Virgins, vamps and heroines
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This delightful selection of moving images from the past shows on screen roles and highlights the off camera activities of women, in the pioneering days of Australias silent cinema. The featured scenes are from the following films: A Maidens distress (1911) ; The Joan of Arc of Loos (1916) ; The Woman suffers (1918) ; The Breaking of the Drought (1920) ; Sunshine Sally (1922) ; Jewelled nights (1925) ; Painted daughters (1925) ; Those who love (1926) ; The Far Paradise (1928) ; The Cheaters (1929).
results.title_for_label: Women of the silent era : Virgins, vamps and heroines

results.title: Women of Aibom: in the time before before
results.creator_credit: Boris Cook and Department of Information and Extension Services
results.brief_description: The making of clay pots is very important for the women of Aibom. Itm is their means of barter for the food which is grown in other villages. The methods of making, decorating and firing the pots are shown.

results.title: Women in the workforce: changes
results.creator_credit: Karin Altmann, Kent Chadwick and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows the changing roles of women in the workforce, including individual cases of women undertaking careers which were once traditionally exclusively male, or male dominated. The women working in non-traditional jobs include a tram driver, an electrician, a gardener, a bank manager, a plumber, an explosives expert and a lead singer in a band.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karin Altmann, Kent Chadwick and Victorian Film Corporation

results.title: Women in rock
results.brief_description: All the legendary women of Rock n Roll are brought together in this collage of artists and their music. Through a music-driven mix of rare historical footage, music videos, riveting live performances and personal interviews, the lives and times of the greatest women in rock history are revealed. Featured musical performances include Carole King, Aretha Franklin, Tina Turner, Janis Joplin, Pat Benatar and Madonna, among others.

results.title: Women in management: threat or opportunity
results.creator_credit: Barbara Jampel, CRM Productions and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Examines the effects of the women’s liberation movement in several different organisations and then shows the many ways, both good and bad, in which leaders and managers are dealing with the situation. Shows how a traditionally male-dominated company has adapted to changing sex roles through an organised program. This film can be used to explore the possible attitudes and hindrances to career progress which girls may face. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Women in mainstream cinema
results.creator_credit: Geoff Cawthorn, Ian Phipps, Margaret Pomeranz, AFTRS and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: Why are women so absent in terms of story, character and integrity, age and exprience in mainstream cinema? Is it just too threatening to have women portrayed as they are in real life, or is it that women’s issues are not real issues? Why could women on screen in the 30’s and 40’s be much more than the undevelopped romantic props they often are today. Hear what top Australian critics think and then have your say.

results.title: Women in kimono
results.creator_credit: Japan. National Tourist Organisation and Koga Productions
results.brief_description: A look at Japanese culture showing the influence of nature in all spheres of life. With no narration, using only Japanese music as background, the film shows the design of fabrics for kimonos, the making of delicate porcelain, silk screen painting and ikebana.

results.creator_credit: John Oliver, British Railways and Topical Press Agency
results.brief_description: Shows the response by the women of Britain during the second World War performing the multitude of tasks, normally carried out by men, necessary to keep the railways running efficiently.

results.title: Women and work: Changes over three generations
results.brief_description: There are many factors which have influenced the changes that have taken place in the world of paid work for women, these include: access to higher education; Equal Opportunity laws; the availability of child care; the impact of domestic and work-related technology; and, family leave for fathers. This video is based on interviews with three Australian women, each representing a different generation. Lynne McLennan, a 37 year old senior public servant, Rosemary West, a well known 53 year old journalist with a perspective on working in the 1960s and Marcella Pearce, a 74 year old retired secretary who began working in the 1930s. The video is presented in five segments: Career Decisions; Pregnancy and child care; Changes in the workplace; Issues in the workplace and Personal values. Teachers notes are included.
